Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Analyzing the Sequential Structure of Music Audio

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The proposal offers an innovative approach to automatic music audio analysis using signal processing and harmonic methods. This is a contribution to the field of Music Information Retrieval (MIR) based on isolating chord sequences in western tonal music archives. The approach is modeled in part on work in bioinformatics, particularly work in structure alignment. The proposed work intends to expand on current approaches to music analysis whcih are limited because of insufficient attention to temporality - a key aspect of musical composition. A new signal processing method is proposed for the isolation of chords and chord sequences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project aimed at extending the understanding and usefulness of music data, through the research, development and application of computational approaches and tools.  The focus was on the development of “listening machines” able to recognize chords, structure and instrumentation from recorded music, and to characterize the similarities that exist between musical pieces. Developing listening machines has many potential applications, including the organization and study of large music collections, the creation of music recommendation services and personalized radio streams, or the development of interactive music systems for performance, composition and education. This work sits at the intersection of the fields of music, electronic engineering and computer science, and seeks to advance the state of the art in all of them.

The project team investigated the optimal design of computational music analysis approaches, with a focus on the interplay between feature design and learning, temporal modeling and classification. Our research led to systems able to automatically transcribe music audio into chord sequences; generate lead sheets and guitar tablatures on recordings of popular music; segment signals into bars or sections such as chorus, verse and bridge; find motifs and other repetitive patterns in music; identify cover songs out of collections of millions of tracks; recognize instruments; and accompany solo melodies with fitting harmonies. This work has led to more than 30 papers in high-impact conferences and journals, and significantly contributed in methods, data, open-source software and educational materials to the scientific community. 

The award also enabled the development of the Science of Music initiative, an outreach program for using music and music technology as a vehicle for science, math and engineering education. The program started as an after-school workshop, and now includes an online collection of educational videos, tutorials and DIY kits that have attracted hundreds of thousands of views and engages over a thousand followers. The initiative makes use of hands on activities such as building speakers from plastic cups, drawing mixers and synthesizers on paper, or building simple audio circuitry, to address fundamental topics in physics, computer science and mathematics. We believe that the general appeal of music makes it an excellent medium for reaching young students, especially those that have been traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering.

This project supported the work of graduate students, including research leading towards four doctoral dissertations, and multiple research experiences for undergraduate students with strong participation from women and other under-served groups in STEM education. Many of these students have gone into higher education and positions in industry, working on music informatics, data science and engineering.
